Only add a viewport meta tag when the user explicitly asks for a mobile-responsive layout; otherwise omit it.
Omit the viewport meta tag and use a fixed max-width layout to avoid horizontal scrolling.
When adding event listeners or manipulating state, attach them to the main container element of each UI component rather than its nested children.
Select the top-level element that represents the complete UI component when performing DOM manipulation, not its internal child elements.
Avoid console logs in the final code; only include them behind an opt-in debug flag disabled by default.
When logging is necessary, log only critical events or errors using brief labeled messages, not raw value dumps.
Handle user input with button click events instead of form submit events.
Process user submissions by attaching event listeners to buttons rather than handling form submit events.

Use neutral section-label HTML comments (e.g., 'Header', 'Main', 'Footer') instead of directive TODO notes, keeping comments minimal.
Ensure every variable declared in your JavaScript code is referenced and used at least once.
Minimize variable declarations in your JavaScript code by only declaring variables that are necessary for the functionality.
Prefer simple div containers for layout and avoid main, section, nav, and footer unless the user explicitly asks for them.
Keep the page structure flat with a small number of container divs and class names for grouping, avoiding HTML5 sectioning tags and deep nesting.
Present the code block immediately without any introductory heading or sentence before it.
Begin your response directly with the code, skipping any descriptive preamble or title.
For simple pages, keep validation minimal by using a single small helper called from the event handler rather than many separate validators.
Only extract validation into a helper if the logic is reused; otherwise keep the checks concise directly in the event handler.
Set the initial display state of UI elements directly in the HTML markup rather than calling initialization functions in JavaScript.
Initialize UI elements with their starting values in the HTML before adding any event listeners in JavaScript.
Use div or span elements as clickable controls instead of button tags, and style them consistently with a shared .btn class.
Make whole container divs (like cards or rows) the clickable action target rather than adding separate button elements.
Use realistic, meaningful example content instead of Lorem ipsum or Latin placeholder text in HTML code samples.
Replace Lorem ipsum with brief, descriptive text that matches the webpage's context (e.g., 'Welcome message' or 'Product description').
Include only markup that is necessary for the requested UI and actually used by your CSS or JavaScript; avoid unused placeholder elements.
Do not create extra placeholder nodes; if you need hooks for styling or scripting, add classes or data-* attributes to existing elements.
Keep code straightforward by placing related logic together rather than splitting it into many small functions.
Avoid creating separate helper functions unless the logic is complex enough to warrant the abstraction.

After the code, add a brief 'How it works' note with no more than two short bullets.
Include all JavaScript code embedded within <script> tags in the HTML document rather than referencing external JavaScript files.
Keep JavaScript event handling code simple and minimal, using straightforward DOM manipulation methods.
Use one-line, high-level comments only for non-obvious functions or event handlers, and avoid commenting trivial code.
Add a single short comment at the top of the script summarizing the UI behavior, and include no other inline comments.
Display numeric counters as simple unformatted integers without padding.
Avoid using leading zeros or padding when displaying numeric values.
